item.title: Ask
item.description: Ask open questions. If you ask someone to justify their views, they are likely to just become defensive and the conversation may become a battle with no winners. Ask gentle, open questions about their hopes and emotions. For example: ‘Can I ask what you hoped for?’

item.title: Listen
item.description: This is not about you being right and them being wrong. Try to understand their concerns and motivations. Ask more open questions. If they have many concerns, focus on the biggest first.

item.title: Reflect
item.description: Show you understand. Repeat back what they have said to show that you have really heard what they have to say. For example: ‘So, you are worried that the NHS is under too much pressure?’

item.title: Agree
item.description: Find common ground. This may not be easy at first but if you focus on their goals and emotions you will probably find something in common. For example: ‘I agree, I’m really worried that in the future the NHS won’t be there for me and my family.’

item.title: Discuss
item.description: Share your personal point of view. Facts alone won’t change minds, that’s likely to just become an argument. People think in emotional stories. So, tell yours. Focus on how your agreed subject will impact you and your family & friends. For example: Less money for the NHS ‘I worry that the NHS won’t be there for me and my family with less money’

item.title: We have the facts
item.description: TalkAboutBrex has key facts at your fingertips, if you need it. But remember, it’s not about being ‘right’ or winning an argument. Stopping Brexit is about protecting whose we care about. Try to think in stories and focus on how it will impact those you care about.

item.title: Be patient & informed
item.description: Some people will never change their minds, so don’t try. But plenty of people will. Focus on them. These 5 steps won’t necessarily happen in the order here and it may take many gentle conversations. You may have to think on your feet but remember - it’s not worth falling out over. Good luck & have a Happy Christmas.

item.title: Brexit has already cost billions
item.description: The Bank of England has said that Brexit has already cost the UK £40 billion. That is around £900 per home.

item.title: EU migrants use the NHS less
item.description: Most EU migrants are young and healthy and so are less likely to use NHS.

item.title: Immigrants give more than they take
item.description: On average, migrants from the EU contribute around £2,300 more to the UK than they take.

item.title: Play nicely!
item.description: Remember… your point of view will be better received if you find some common ground on a subject first.

item.title: The single market is a good thing
item.description: The single market makes trade between EU companies easy by making all members keep to the same standards. This means that we know the toasters produced in the UK, Germany or France are all of at least the same quality and so we don’t need to check them when they come in or out. This keeps us all safe and makes it much easier to do business in Europe.

item.title: There will be less money for NHS
item.description: Nearly all economists say we will be poorer after Brexit and so we are not going to get the extra £350 million a week for the NHS that we were promised. Even Nigel Farage said he could not guarantee we would get that money.

item.title: Try a different subject?
item.description: As long as it doesn’t cause an argument…

item.title: UK Nationals may have to leave the EU
item.description: If the UK leaves the EU, people from the UK will lose the automatic right to live, work and retire there. 1.2 million people from UK currently live in the EU. What will happen to them?

item.title: We agree with the EU most of the time
item.description: The UK has only lost a vote against a suggested EU law 56 out of 2536 times since 1999, so for around 98% of the time we agree with the EU.

item.title: We are in control of the big things
item.description: In really important areas like taxation, allowing another country to join the EU or citizen’s rights and justice, if the UK does not agree to an idea that has come from the EU, we can stop it the EU from doing it.

item.title: We can control immigration from EU
item.description: EU law states that people from the EU must either have a job or enough money to not be a burden on the UK’s public services and have medical insurance to be allowed to come and live here.

item.title: We control immigration from outside EU
item.description: As members of the EU, we are in complete control of immigration from countries outside the EU. We control immigration to the UK from 169 countries of the world.

item.title: We have a free trade deal with EU
item.description: As a member of the EU’s Single Market, we have free trade deals with all 27 EU countries. That is over 500 million customers. If we leave the Single Market, we will lose these agreements and will have to start negotiating with the EU again.

item.title: We have free trade deals outside the EU
item.description: As part of the EU, we have free trade deals with over 50 countries outside of the EU from South Africa to South Korea. If we leave the EU, we will lose these agreements and will have to start negotiating ourselves, which can take a long time - the EU’s deal with Canada took 7 years to agree.

item.title: We help decide what the EU will do
item.description: In less important areas, if the European Council want to do something they take a vote and need at least 50% of the countries to agree to it. So, while we’re in the EU, we get to discuss and debate and play a part in deciding what all the EU countries do.

item.title: We need EU people to work in NHS
item.description: 62,000 people from the EU currently work in the NHS. But the NHS is still short of 35,000 nurses and nearly 10,000 doctors. What would we do without the doctors and nurses from the EU?

item.title: We rely on EU for medicine
item.description: The UK imports 37 million packs of medicine each month from the EU. Some medicine don’t keep for long so we need them to get here quickly and regularly.

item.title: We will be poorer in the long run
item.description: The Government estimates that the UK economy will be between 3.9% to 9.3% poorer over next 15 years if we go ahead with Brexit.
